ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Academic writing at the university level. This included 1) choosing a topic to write about, 2) how to make a paper contribute to ongoing academic discussions, 3) how to overcome writer's block, 4) how to cite easily, 5) how to allow emotions/multicultural dialect/creativity into papers, and so much more. I am extremely grateful to have learned so many valuable skills in a supportive, engaging setting.
I learned not only how to write in this course, but also how to provide and critically think about useful feedback from my professor and classmates, as well as how to read for understanding.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Many peer interactions, even when each of us was writing on different topics.
The course focuses on interesting topics (research papers) and teaches how to write strong, evidence based papers. One weakness is that some of the assignments seemed unnecessary.

A strength of this course was that it was centered on student learning, rather than perfection. A lot of assignments focused on giving and receiving feedback, which was useful for reflection and improvement. Thus, I learned a lot about the writing process from taking this course. One thing that could be improved might be the expanded availability of office hours not only during the more intense parts of the semester (i.e. around paper deadlines) but within the entire semester so that the student-instructor bond could be strengthened.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I took the class because I needed a WR credit. I left with a WR credit but also many useful writing skills I wasn't expecting to gain. The free-topic final essay made the class much more interesting than other ENGL 114 or seminar classes (where you're usually stuck with one topic for an entire semester)!
Yes. I think this course is a great introduction to the philosophy of mind, develops valuable writing skills, and is taught by an amazing professor.

I would definitely recommend this course to other students, especially those who aren't very proficient in writing. This course has informed a lot of my knowledge that will manifest in future writing-intense courses, and I have a great impression of Yale's writing course offerings after taking this course. 
I also made friends in this course, since there is a lot of productive collaboration, which is always great!
